slide1.title: Meet Your Trusted Insurance Agent
slide1.subtitle: Building Trust Through Transparency
slide1.introduction: I'm committed to providing you with honest, transparent, and personalized insurance guidance. With years of experience and licenses in multiple states, I'm here to help you find the best coverage that fits your needs and budget.

slide2.title: Getting to Know You
slide2.subtitle: Understanding Your Financial Goals
slide2.description: Before we explore retirement planning options, let's understand your unique situation and goals.
questions: What are your primary financial goals for retirement?
Why are you thinking about retirement planning now?
What retirement savings or plans do you currently have in place?
How do you envision your lifestyle during retirement?
What concerns do you have about your retirement planning?
Have you thought about what would happen if you became seriously ill?
How important is it to you to leave a legacy for your family?
What is your current approach to saving for the future?

slide3.title: Traditional Retirement Savings Options
slide3.subtitle: 401(k) Plans

product.name: 401(k) Plans
product.description: Employer-sponsored retirement savings plans that allow employees to contribute a portion of their salary on a pre-tax basis.

advantages: Higher contribution limits compared to IRAs ($23,000 in 2025)
Potential employer matching contributions (free money)
Contributions reduce taxable income in the year made
Tax-deferred growth on investments
Automatic payroll deductions make saving easy
disadvantages: Limited investment options based on employer's plan
Early withdrawals before age 59½ incur 10% penalty plus taxes
Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs) begin at age 73
RMDs increase taxable income, potentially pushing you into higher tax bracket
No access to funds without penalty until age 59½ (except hardship withdrawals)
If you leave your job, you may need to roll over or face fees
Market risk - your account can lose 20-50% in downturns

slide4.title: Traditional Retirement Savings Options
slide4.subtitle: Traditional IRAs

product.name: Traditional IRAs
product.description: Individual retirement accounts that allow tax-deductible contributions and tax-deferred growth until withdrawal.

advantages: Contributions may be tax-deductible, reducing current taxable income
Wide range of investment options (stocks, bonds, mutual funds, ETFs)
Tax-deferred growth until withdrawal
You control your investment choices
Can be opened independently of employer
disadvantages: Lower contribution limits compared to 401(k)s ($7,000 in 2025)
Early withdrawals before age 59½ incur 10% penalty plus taxes
Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs) begin at age 73
RMDs force withdrawals even if you don't need the money
Withdrawals are taxed as ordinary income (potentially at higher rates)
Tax deduction may be limited or eliminated based on income and employer plan participation
Market risk - your account can lose 20-50% in downturns

slide5.title: Traditional Retirement Savings Options
slide5.subtitle: Roth IRAs

product.name: Roth IRAs
product.description: Individual retirement accounts funded with after-tax dollars, allowing tax-free withdrawals in retirement.

advantages: Qualified withdrawals are completely tax-free, including earnings
No Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs) during your lifetime
Contributions can be withdrawn at any time without taxes or penalties
Wide range of investment options
Can be opened independently of employer
disadvantages: Contributions are made with after-tax dollars (no immediate tax deduction)
Income limits restrict eligibility for high earners (phases out at $161,000-$176,000 for single filers in 2025)
Lower contribution limits compared to 401(k)s ($7,000 in 2025)
Early withdrawal of earnings before age 59½ incurs 10% penalty plus taxes
Must wait 5 years after opening account to withdraw earnings tax-free
Market risk - your account can lose 20-50% in downturns
No access to funds for emergencies without penalty (earnings portion)

slide6.title: Traditional Retirement Savings Options
slide6.subtitle: Roth 401(k) Plans

product.name: Roth 401(k) Plans
product.description: Employer-sponsored plans combining features of 401(k)s and Roth IRAs, offering after-tax contributions and tax-free withdrawals.

advantages: Higher contribution limits than Roth IRAs ($23,000 in 2025)
No income limits for contributions (unlike Roth IRAs)
Tax-free withdrawals in retirement, including earnings
Potential employer matching contributions
Automatic payroll deductions
disadvantages: Contributions are made with after-tax dollars (no immediate tax deduction)
Limited investment options based on employer's plan
Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs) begin at age 73 (unless rolled over to Roth IRA)
Early withdrawals before age 59½ incur 10% penalty plus taxes on earnings
Market risk - your account can lose 20-50% in downturns
RMDs can force taxable distributions if not rolled over

slide7.title: Traditional Retirement Savings Options
slide7.subtitle: Other Retirement Accounts

product.name: 403(b) & SEP IRAs
product.description: Additional retirement savings options for specific groups: 403(b) for educators/non-profits, SEP IRAs for self-employed individuals.

advantages: 403(b): Similar to 401(k) but for educators and non-profit employees
SEP IRA: Higher contribution limits for self-employed (up to $69,000 or 25% of compensation in 2025)
Tax-deferred growth
Employer contributions possible (SEP IRA)
disadvantages: 403(b): Same limitations as 401(k) - RMDs, early withdrawal penalties, market risk
SEP IRA: Lower contribution limits than 401(k) for employees ($7,000 in 2025)
Early withdrawal penalties before age 59½
RMDs begin at age 73
Market risk - accounts can lose 20-50% in downturns
Limited access to funds without penalty

slide8.title: Real-World Scenarios
slide8.subtitle: Early Withdrawal Penalty
slide8.warning: Traditional retirement accounts offer NO protection for these scenarios

scenario.title: The Emergency Withdrawal
scenario.situation: John, age 52, has $200,000 in his 401(k). He faces a medical emergency and needs $50,000 to cover expenses. He decides to withdraw from his 401(k).
scenario.problem: John must pay a 10% early withdrawal penalty ($5,000) plus ordinary income taxes on the full $50,000. If he's in the 22% tax bracket, he'll pay $11,000 in taxes. Total cost: $16,000 in taxes and penalties.
scenario.impact: John receives only $34,000 from his $50,000 withdrawal. His retirement savings are permanently reduced, and he loses the future growth on that $50,000. Traditional retirement accounts offer no flexibility for emergencies without severe penalties.

slide9.title: Real-World Scenarios
slide9.subtitle: Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs)
slide9.warning: Traditional retirement accounts offer NO protection for these scenarios

scenario.title: The Forced Withdrawal Problem
scenario.situation: Maria, age 73, has $1.5 million in her Traditional IRA. She doesn't need the money yet and wants to let it continue growing. However, she must take Required Minimum Distributions (RMDs).
scenario.problem: At age 73, Maria must withdraw approximately $54,745 (about 3.65% of her account). This withdrawal is taxed as ordinary income, potentially pushing her into a higher tax bracket. She must continue taking larger RMDs each year, even if she doesn't need the money.
scenario.impact: Maria loses control over when to access her money. The forced withdrawals increase her taxable income, potentially affecting Social Security taxation, Medicare premiums, and her overall tax situation. She can't preserve the money for her heirs without paying taxes first.

slide10.title: Real-World Scenarios
slide10.subtitle: Market Downturn Impact
slide10.warning: Traditional retirement accounts offer NO protection for these scenarios

scenario.title: The Market Crash
scenario.situation: Robert, age 60, has been saving diligently in his 401(k) for 30 years. His account has grown to $800,000. A major market downturn occurs, and the market drops 35%.
scenario.problem: Robert's 401(k) loses $280,000, dropping to $520,000. He's planning to retire in 5 years, but now his retirement is in jeopardy. He has no protection from market losses - his entire retirement is at risk.
scenario.impact: Robert may need to delay retirement, work longer, or reduce his retirement lifestyle. Traditional retirement accounts offer no downside protection. If the market doesn't recover before he needs the money, his retirement plans are permanently damaged.

slide11.title: Real-World Scenarios
slide11.subtitle: Serious Illness Impact
slide11.warning: Traditional retirement accounts offer NO protection for these scenarios

scenario.title: The Critical Illness
scenario.situation: Sarah, age 58, is diagnosed with a critical illness. She needs $100,000 for medical expenses and to cover her living costs while she can't work. She has $300,000 in her 401(k) and $50,000 in savings.
scenario.problem: If Sarah withdraws from her 401(k), she'll pay 10% penalty ($10,000) plus taxes. Her savings won't cover everything. Traditional retirement accounts offer no living benefits for critical illness - she must choose between financial penalties or not having enough money for treatment.
scenario.impact: Sarah faces a devastating choice: pay penalties to access her retirement money when she needs it most, or struggle financially during a health crisis. Traditional retirement accounts don't provide protection for critical, chronic, or terminal illnesses.

slide12.title: A Different Perspective
slide12.subtitle: Becoming Your Own Bank
questions: Do you currently own a bank?
Can you take money out of your own bank right now?
If you need to buy a car, what do you do?
If you want to buy a house, what do you do?
Who do you pay interest to?
slide12.description: Most people rely on traditional banks and financial institutions for every major purchase. But what if there was a better way?

example.scenario: You need a $35,000 car. You go to a bank or dealership for financing.
example.problem: You pay $7,060 in interest to the bank. That's money you'll never see again. Plus, you're locked into monthly payments for 5 years, regardless of your financial situation.

example.scenario: You want to buy a $400,000 home. You get a 30-year mortgage from a bank.
example.problem: You pay $558,680 in interest over 30 years - more than the house itself cost! That's money going to the bank, not building your wealth. You're paying for the bank's profits, not your future.

slide15.title: The True Cost of Traditional Banking
slide15.subtitle: What You're Really Paying

costs.description: Average household credit card debt interest per year
Typical personal loan interest over 3 years

slide15.summary: Over a lifetime, the average American pays hundreds of thousands of dollars in interest to banks and financial institutions. This money could be working for YOU instead.

slide16.title: What If You Could Be Your Own Bank?
slide16.subtitle: Imagine the Possibilities
questions: What if you could borrow from yourself instead of a bank?
What if you could pay interest to yourself instead of a bank?
What if you could access your money when you need it, without penalties?
What if you could protect yourself from market downturns?
What if you could access funds for critical illness without penalties?
What if you could solve ALL the problems we've discussed?
slide16.description: There IS a way to become your own bank. A way to keep your money working for you, not for financial institutions. A way to solve the retirement problems, the banking problems, and the protection problems - all in one solution.

slide17.title: The Solution You've Been Waiting For
slide17.subtitle: Indexed Universal Life (IUL)
slide17.description: Finally, a financial strategy that solves ALL the problems we've discussed. A way to become your own bank, protect your retirement, and secure your future - all in one powerful solution.

slide18.title: Who is IUL Good For?
slide18.subtitle: The Perfect Fit
slide18.description: IUL is an ideal financial strategy for individuals who want comprehensive protection, tax advantages, and the ability to become their own bank. Here's who benefits most:

characteristics.title: Wanting a PERMANENT Death Benefit / Leaving a Legacy
characteristics.description: IUL provides permanent life insurance coverage that never expires, ensuring your loved ones are protected and your legacy is preserved.

characteristics.title: Middle to High-Income Earners Looking for Tax-Free Retirement
characteristics.description: Perfect for those seeking tax-free growth and withdrawals in retirement. Recommended contribution: 10x your age on a monthly basis (e.g., age 40 = $400/month minimum).

characteristics.title: Become Your Own Bank
characteristics.description: Ideal for those who want to borrow from themselves, pay interest to themselves, and have flexible access to their money without penalties.

characteristics.title: Well-Rounded Portfolio
characteristics.description: Best for individuals who already have other investments and want IUL as part of a diversified financial strategy.

characteristics.title: Maxing Out 401(k) Match or Roth IRA
characteristics.description: Perfect for those who are already maximizing their employer 401(k) match or Roth IRA contributions and want additional tax-advantaged growth.

slide18.cta: If this sounds like you, IUL could be your perfect financial solution.

slide19.title: Where Does an IUL Fit in a Retirement Plan?
slide19.subtitle: Risk vs. Reward Comparison
slide19.description: See how IUL compares to traditional investment options in terms of risk and potential reward.
slide19.insight: IUL offers superior reward for its risk level compared to traditional investments

slide20.title: Properly Structuring an IUL
slide20.subtitle: Understanding the Two Buckets
slide20.description: Your monthly premium is divided into two essential components that work together to build your wealth.

relationship.title: The Balance
points: Higher Death Benefit = Lower Cash Value
Lower Death Benefit = Higher Cash Value

cashValueFeatures.title: Cash Value Benefits
points: Floor protection: 0% minimum (never lose when market drops)

whyStructureMatters.title: Why Proper Structure is Essential
points: Maximizes cash value accumulation for your goals
Ensures you can access funds when needed

slide20.cta: Proper structure = Maximum accumulation for your financial goals

slide21.title: What is Indexing Strategy?
slide21.subtitle: How Your Money Grows
slide21.description: Your cash value is linked to market performance, but protected from market losses.

keyPoints.title: Follows Market Index
keyPoints.description: Your growth is tied to S&P 500 performance

keyPoints.title: Protected from Losses
keyPoints.description: You never lose money when the market goes down

keyPoints.title: Participates in Gains
keyPoints.description: You benefit when the market goes up

slide21.visualNote: Your money is NOT invested in stocks - it follows an index

slide22.title: Understanding Key Terms
slide22.subtitle: Floor & Cap Explained

floor.title: 0% Floor
floor.explanation: Even if the market drops 20%, 30%, or 50%, your account never goes below 0%

cap.title: 10% Cap (Example)
cap.explanation: If the market gains 15%, you get up to 10% (the cap). This protects the insurance company.

slide22.note: Actual caps vary by company and policy

slide23.title: Important: Your Money is NOT Invested
slide23.subtitle: How Indexing Works

directInvestment.title: Direct Stock Investment
points: Full market risk - can lose everything

indexing.title: Indexing Strategy (IUL)
points: Your money stays in the policy
Growth is calculated based on index performance
Participates in gains up to cap

slide23.keyMessage: Your money follows the index, but is not directly invested in it

slide24.title: How Indexing Works - Simple Example
slide24.subtitle: See the Difference

scenarios.explanation: Market up 8%, you get full 8% (under cap)

slide24.summary: You participate in gains, protected from losses

slide25.subtitle: Let's Run Your Personal Illustration
